sentence: In a tumultuous session on Tuesday, the benchmark U.S. indices clawed back some of the losses made in their recent selloff, surging into the close after swinging between gains and losses through much of the day.
The blue-chip Dow Jones Industrial Average ended more than 500 points higher, with nearly all of its components in the green as bargain hunters poured into the markets in the latter part of trading.
Gains were led by Home Depot ( HD ), up 4.5%, and Apple ( AAPL ), which rose 4.2%.
Materials and tech stocks led the S&P 500 higher, while the Nasdaq stayed well above water by the bell.
The markets all ended near their high points of the day, and volumes on the benchmarks were all ahead of their average volumes -- including more than double for the Dow.

Questions over whether the selling had more room to run or a bottom had been reached drove the back-and-forth moves, with the whipsaw session coming after Asian and European markets took their cues from Monday's US trading, extending the rout to global markets.
Goldman Sachs said the sharp selloff was "technical and positioning-driven rather than fundamentally-based" and kept its year-end target for the S&P 500.
Investor Carl Icahn told CNBC that the market will bounce back and get through the panic due to the tax benefits passing through the economy and positive fundamentals.
In political news, President Donald Trump said he'd welcome a government shutdown -- the second in less than a month -- if Democrats are unwilling to meet his demands on immigration.
And the day's economic data showed that December's Job Openings and Labor Turnover Survey fell to 5.81 million, missing estimates for 5.9 million.
Wednesday's calendar has mostly Federal Reserve speakers including Dallas President Robert Kaplan, New York's William Dudley, Chicago's Charles Evans and San Francisco's John Williams.

Here's where the markets stood by the close:

(+) MU (+11.37%) Needham upgrades to strong buy from buy with $76 price target

(-) MARK (-24.86%) Says will issue proper response to "sloppy short driven report" by J Capital
